Indications and doses

Local treatment of inflammation (short term),

To the eye using eye ointment

  • For adults
    Apply every 1–2 hours until controlled then reduce frequency.
  • For adults
    Apply 2–4 times a day, alternatively apply at night when used in combination with eye drops.
  • For children
    Apply every 1–2 hours until controlled then reduce frequency.
  • For children
    Apply 2–4 times a day, alternatively apply at night when used in combination with eye drops.

Severe inflammatory skin disorders such as eczemas unresponsive to less potent corticosteroids, Psoriasis,

To the skin

  • For adults
    Apply 1–2 times a day, to be applied thinly.
  • For children
    Apply 1–2 times a day, to be applied thinly.

Suppression of inflammatory and allergic disorders, Congenital adrenal hyperplasia,

By intramuscular injection or by slow intravenous injection or by intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    Usual dose 0.5–5 mg daily.
  • For adults
    4–20 mg, repeated up to 4 times in 24 hours.

Oral ulceration,

By mouth using soluble tablets

  • For adults
    500 micrograms 4 times a day, to be dissolved in 20 mL water and rinsed around the mouth; not to be swallowed.
  • For children 12–17 years
    500 micrograms 4 times a day, to be dissolved in 20 mL water and rinsed around the mouth; not to be swallowed.

Potency of preperations

Betamethasone valerate 0.025% cream and ointment: moderate.

Betamethasone valerate 0.1% cream, lotion, medicated plasters, ointment, and scalp application: potent.

Betamethasone valerate 0.12% foam: potent.

Betamethasone dipropionate 0.05% cream, lotion, and ointment: potent.

Advice when patient is pregnant

With systemic use

Readily crosses the placenta.

Transient effect on fetal movements and heart rate.

Contra indications

Known side effects

Specific side effects

notKnown: local sensitivity reactions, adrenal suppression following prolonged use in neonates in neonates, corneal thinning, scleral thinning, candidal infection, exacerbation of local infection,

Directions for administration

With intravenous use in children

For intravenous infusion, dilute with Glucose 5% or Sodium Chloride 0.9%.

With intravenous use in adults

For intravenous infusion (as sodium phosphate) (Betnesol ), give continuously or intermittently or via drip tubing in Glucose 5% or Sodium chloride 0.9%.

Advice for patients and carers

With oral use in adults

Patient counselling is advised for betamethasone soluble tablets (steroid card).

With oral (topical) use

Patient counselling is advised for betamethasone soluble tablets (administration).

With topical use

Patient counselling is advised for betamethasone cream, ointment, scalp application and foam (application).

Cautions regarding administration

  • When used by ear: avoid prolonged use
  • With topical use: use of more than 100 g per week of 0.1% preparation likely to cause adrenal suppression

Unlicensed use

With oral (topical) use in children

Betamethasone soluble tablets not licensed for use as mouthwash or in oral ulceration.

With topical use in children

Betacap , Betnovate and Betnovate-RD are not licensed for use in children under 1 year.

Bettamousse is not licensed for use in children under 6 years.

With intranasal use or when used by ear in children

Licensed for use in children (age range not specified by manufacturers).

Profession specific information

Dental practitioners

With oral (topical) use

Betamethasone Soluble Tablets 500 micrograms may be prescribed for oral ulceration.
